**Q:** *Can you explain what you define as a connector? Are all these connectors live? Specifically, as new files or records are added, will the AI automatically ingest them in real-time?*

**A:**  
A **connector** is simply a lightweight service or plugin that knows how to access a specific data source (like a file share, database, cloud drive, or API) and make that data available to the **data plane** in a consistent, structured way.

- **Are they â€œliveâ€?**  
  Connectors can run in either *real-time* (streaming updates) or *batch mode* (scheduled syncs). For something like a proposal library, youâ€™d typically use a *hybrid approach*:
  - New files dropped into an active folder can be auto-detected and indexed in near real-time.
  - Legacy or archival files can be bulk-ingested on a schedule or as needed.

- **Does the AI auto-ingest?**  
  The **data plane** includes a simple orchestration layer that listens for changes from the connectors. So when new files or records appear, the system automatically processes, indexes, and makes them available to the AI â€” with no manual step required.

This means the proposalbot always has the freshest version of your proposals, past performance data, or templates to work from â€” without users worrying about uploading each file by hand.

---

parts:
Youâ€™re right â€” letâ€™s break that down honestly, step by step:  

If the network drive has **Word docs**, **Excel files**, and **PDFs**, you really do need *different extraction logic* for each format. You canâ€™t parse an XLSX with the same code that handles a DOCX or a PDF.

So the real truth is:  
âœ… **Each unique data format needs its own parser.**  
âœ… Those parsers can be bundled into a single connector if they share the same access and orchestration pattern â€” but in practice, itâ€™s clearer and more maintainable to think of each as its own connector.  
âœ… The â€œnetwork driveâ€ or â€œSharePointâ€ just defines *how you get the files*. The format defines *what you do with them*.  

So a clearer, more honest version would be:  

---

**Q:** *Regarding SharePoint or network drives as connectors, do these count as a single connector, or does each file type (e.g., XLSX, DOC, PDF) on the network drive count as a separate connector?*

**A:**  
You can think of a connector as defined by:
- **Source type** (file share, database, API, etc.)
- **Data format** (XLSX, DOCX, PDF, etc.)
- **Access method** (credentials, network path, API key, etc.)

These three factors decide what code you actually need. So for a single network drive with multiple file formats:
- Youâ€™d realistically need at least **one connector per data format**, since each one has a different parser and logic.
- Youâ€™d reuse the *location* and *credentials* as configuration for each connector.

So in your example â€” if you have Word docs, Excel files, and PDFs â€” youâ€™d have **three connectors**, all pointed to the same drive but handling different formats.

This is more robust in real-world usage because it makes debugging, scaling, and extending new formats easier â€” youâ€™re not trying to shoehorn radically different parsers into a single pipeline.

---

This is clearer, more practical, and wonâ€™t surprise anyone later when they find out Excel is breaking the PDF parser!

What infrastructure do these connectors operate on? Are they hosted as Azure Web Apps, Azure Functions, or other services? Do they run on scheduled jobs that pull data, or do they use webhooks that receive pushed data?
And my draft answer (please improve)
Containers running on Azure Kubernetes. A container is an encapsulated software service.  Our platform provides orchestration, authentication, hardware, and network connectivity to these containers, which can run virtually any service.  The containers can and do present REST APIs to receive pushed data (typically through POST or PUT requests), can incorporate scheduling daemons to pull data on a schedule, and for that matter the Hub itself (the central orchestrator) can schedule services to run at specific times.

---

**Q:** *What infrastructure do these connectors operate on? Are they hosted as Azure Web Apps, Azure Functions, or other services? Do they run on scheduled jobs that pull data, or do they use webhooks that receive pushed data?*

**A:**  
Our connectors run as **containers** on an Azure Kubernetes cluster. A container is a fully encapsulated software service that includes its own code, dependencies, and configuration.  

The platform provides:  
- **Orchestration** â€” to start, stop, and scale containers as needed  
- **Authentication** â€” secure access to data sources and credentials  
- **Compute & network** â€” the hardware and routing needed for real-time or batch operations

**How they work:**  
- Connectors can expose **REST APIs** to receive pushed data (using POST, PUT, or webhooks).
- They can also run **scheduled jobs** to pull data from a source on a defined interval.
- The orchestrator itself can schedule containers to run at specific times or in response to events.

This gives you flexible options: some connectors run continuously for real-time updates, while others run on a daily or hourly schedule, depending on what your data sources require.

---

This version keeps all your truth, clarifies how push and pull patterns coexist, and avoids any accidental gaps.

What infrastructure does the "Data Fusion" component use? Is it a vector database, a data warehouse, or another type of system?

The Data Fusion Plane is a software layer that integrates multiple components, including file systems, SQL database, NoSQL databases, document databases (e.g., MongoDB), simulations, enterprise services with APIs, and others. Individual services may integrate their own storage layer (e.g., a vector database for an AI service), but the data fusion layer is the layer that presents a unified view of shared data to all services.

- **File systems** (e.g., cloud storage, network shares)  
- **SQL databases** (for structured records)  
- **NoSQL and document databases** (e.g., MongoDB for unstructured data)

- **Simulations and real-time models**  
- **Enterprise services and APIs** (for data thatâ€™s generated dynamically)

In short: itâ€™s an orchestration and abstraction layer, not a single warehouse â€” so you can plug in the right storage technology for each use case while still delivering a coherent, trusted view to your users.
